Announcement has again been
made by Mr. Maxwell Sauerwein,
assistant treasurer, that students
are eligible to attend tonight's banquet at the Merchants Club in honor of Dr. Ray Vail Orman.
Mr. Sauerwein explained that
uncertainty existed in certain quarters as to whether students could
attend, since they had not received
personal invitations.
"Although undergraduates will
be subject to the uniform $2.50
fee, they need not pay it in cash
immediately," he said. "I am certain that satisfactory arrangements can be made regarding the
payments. Tickets may be secured
at my office in Remsen Hall today, or at the Merchants Club
Prior to the banquet."
Coaches, sports writers, and "just
plain friends" who hate to see Van
Orman go will gather in a final farewell to Dr. Ray Van Orman at a
testimonial banquet to be sponsored
in his honor by the University Varsity Club tonight in the club's headquarters at 206 E. Redwood St. Festivities will open at 7 o'clock.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, has sent word that
he will attend, provided that injuries
he incurred in an automobile accident a few weeks ago permit him to
do so.
Tody Riggs, St. John's grid mentor,
Is the only one of the coaches tendered
Invitations who will definitely attend. Dick Harlow, of Western Maryland, has a speaking engagement in
Pittsburgh tonight while Curley Byrd
University of Maryland official must
attend a meeting in Richmond of the
Executive Board of the Southern
Conference, of which he is a member.
Washington College entertains its
first court foe tonight and Tom Kibler will have to be on the bench with
'Shoremen.
Harlow wrote to Carl W. Schmidt,
President of the Varsity Club, saying,
"I accepted two invitations to speak
In Pittsburg over a month ago and
regret that I cannot be with you to
Pay Van a tribute so richly deserved."
8Yrd and Kibler also expressed regret at being unable to participate in
a tribute to Van Orman.

Poetess Guest Of
Tudor And Stuart
A tea in honor of Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, prominent BaltiInore poetess, will be given today by
the Tudor and Stuart Club at 4
o'clock, at their club rooms in Gil10 .n Hall.
For many years Miss
Reese, who holds a high reputation
for her many poetic and other literarY works, has been an honorary
inernber of the group. Members of
the club will meet the guest of honor,
after which tea. will be served.
Dr. Elmer E. Stoll, professor of
flglis at the University of Minnesota, will give the annual lecture of
the Tudor and Stuart Club, February
16 in Levering Hall. Although Professor Stoll's topic has not been selected as yet, plans have been made
to hold a smoker and banquet in his
honor on that date. The numerous
honorary
and active members of the
club will be invited to
attend.

A gym class exclusively for girl
students in the graduate school
and College for Teachers has been
formed under the direction of Dr.
Wilson Shaffer, head of the intramural athletic department, and
Reuben Baer. The group includes
about 20 girls, who meet every
Wednesday from 8 to 10 p. m. in
the gymnasium.
In order to instruct the class in
basketball, volley ball and other
sports, a P. A. L. instructor has
been secured by the intramural
department. Plans have been
formulated to begin other classes
of girl students after the Christmas holidays.

Local High Schools
Visited By Twelve
Hopkins Students
Classes In Various Subjects
Observed By Largest Practice Teaching Group Here
Senior and junior high school days
returned for 12 students, seven women and five men, the largest group
in recent years to be registered in the
course in teaching in the secondary
schools, as they began observation
work for 1934-1935.
The students, of whom all but one,
a graduate student, are seniors in the
College for Teachers and the College
of Arts and Sciences, attended, during the past two weeks, secondary
school classes in English, history, biology, French, mathematics, commercial geography, and general science
to observe the techniques of teaching
in these subjects. What was noted in
detail was recorded on special blanks
which were submitted within 24 hours
to Dr. E. Earle Franklin, associate in
education here.
Observed Today
An observation in English was held
this morning at Junior High School
No. 49. Yesterday, the practice teachers saw a class in history taught at
the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.
The group visited a mathematics and
French class Wednesday morning at
the new Patterson Park Junior High
School.
Baltimore City College, where a
class in general science was observed, was visited Monday. Other
observations were held at Western
High School, Junior High Schools No.
1 and 41.
List Students
Enrolled in the class, registration
for which is not possible until specified
courses in education have been successfully completed, are: Maurice Sater, graduate student; Bertha Rodgin,
Katheryne Chambers, Alice Eklof,
Dorothy Girdwood, Regina Grau,
Bishop and Hyman M. Levin, seniors
in the College for Teachers; Howard
Fox, B. J. Stinnett, and Arthur Gutman, seniors in the College of Arts
and Sciences.
Ten individual observations in the
subject chosen for teaching, which
are to follow the current ten-group
observations, are to be followed by
a two-week period of practice teaching in the selected subject and in the
same class in which the individual
observations were made.

The Johns Hopkins University has been selected
by the Association of College Editors as one of the
150 American colleges and universities in which The
Literary Digest—A. C. E. Peace Poll will be conducted.
These questions will be asked on the poll ballots,
which are to be distributed in your postoffice boxes
during the week of January 7:
1. Do you believe that the United States can
stay out of another great war?
(a) If the borders of the United States were
invaded, would you bear arms in defense of
your country?
(b) Would you bear arms for the United States
in the invasion of the borders of another
country?
2. Do you believe that a national policy of AN
AMERICAN NAVY AND AIR FORCE
SECOND TO NONE will insure us against
the possibilities of another great war?
3. Do you favor government control of armament and munition industries?
4. Do you approve of the conscription of capital
in time of war, just as has been our historic
procedure in drafting man-power in time of
war?
5. Do you think that, in the pursuit of the stabilization of Peace, it would be a wise policy
for the United States to enter the League of
Nations?
Think over these questions during Christmas vacation. They require serious and lengthy consideration.—STANLEY E. BLUMBERG.

A Figure And His Figure
THE NUMBER "14" seems to have hovered over the
football career of Ray Van Orman with all the persistence of the proverbial income tax. He tutored droves
of Blue Jay gridders to relative pigskin glory for 14
years; undoubtedly the culmination of his uniquely successful coaching efforts was relized in the 14-13 triumph
over Maryland in 1927; first announcement of his intended resignation appeared in the local press on Wednesday, November 14; and tonight, exactly one month
later, he is to be tendered a farewell banquet in tribute
to his character and his achievements.
Possibly there's nothing much that can be added to
the laudations which are due to be heaped this evenrng
on Van's already laurel-bedecked head. But for fear lest
the student viewpoint may not be sufficiently emphasized by the speakers, we are taking the liberty to steal
a march on the toastmaster and exclaim with raised
glass:
Here's to you, Van, in appreciation of your contribution to Hopkins life. You taught us the chant of the
underdog—a grim chant, a solemn chant, but above all
a defiant and a triumphant chant. You didn't know what
overwhelming odds were, and you infused this selfsame
spirit in your men. For this we are deeply grateful;
without it we would be infinitely the poorer.
We hope you'll return to our midst often—say the
14th of every month; better, every 14th day. Until we
meet again, good-bye and good luck!

Culture—Physical
THAT THE athletic department has ushered in a gym
class expressly designed for the College for Teachers
girls probably will cause no end of eyebrow-lifting
among many of our masculine brethren, but it doesn't
surprise us in the least. It seems quite in harmony with
the trend which these young ladies have established
this year; namely, a typical Horatio Alger attitude of
refusing to sink in the academic swim.
Far more important than this rather trivial observation, however, is the commentary to which this project
perhaps unconsciously gives rise. It concerns itself with
the pampered, indolent manner of living which the modern miss has allowed herself to assume, with the inevitable result that she has lost to a great degree that
combination of endurance and hardiness which so
stamped her female progenitors. True, she participates
in many forms of athletics which were totally unknown
or prohibited to her ancestors, but in spite of these patent advantages she seems incapable of growing out of
the "hothouse aura" which, at least in the eyes of this
observer, seems constantly to cloak her. As the prospective occupant of a covered wagon, she would be a
total loss!
Understand that we are reciting from the diary of
the comparatively well-to-do damsel, the type that does

not immediately of its own volition or of necessity seek
employment in the downtown din and thereby lose practically all opportunity of perfecting itself physically,
but which on the contrary spends those nasty but usually necessary pre-marriage years as suits its particular
fancy. We contend that life has become far too easy for
these girls and that they for their part have made no
wholehearted attempts to resist the modern current of
abundant leisure which attend their every move. Even
in these days of depression the maintenance of their
unquestionable comforts and questionable pulchritude
appears to be the particular target of their parents'
forced financial stinting.
So it's with a mixed feeling of relief and elation that
we observe the formation of this feminine gym class. It
reminds us of that current song hit, "Love in Bloomers."

Dr. Mitchell Goes On Record
Following is an excerpt from "Johns Hopkins'
President," an article written by Dr. Broadus Mitchell and published in the Evening Sun, Tuesday, December 11. It offers a new interpretation of the modern purposes and values of a university, and as
such is worthy of reprint and reflection.
Our educational system, in both its public and private agencies, and from bottom to top, has too mucllent itself to the habit now outmoded. It has permittee
itself to be dedicated, by and large, to the preservation
of the established economic order. In the universities
this has been true not only in the departments of the
social studies, but in the more exact sciences as well. Le'
us say that investigators and teachers swore to lollow
truth wherever it led, still the light that guided them wal
apt to be furnished by the prevailing social system. Thir
is not to assess guilt, but simply to state a condition
Economists, sociologists and students of government haw
been preoccupied with description, often slavish and un
imaginative, of what is rather than with intelligent at
tempts at forecast. Where called upon for advice, they
have too often been willing to assume the role of mere
strategists for private enterprise. Presumably acquainted
with theory, they have in the event turned out to be
prime opportunists, hardly rising superior to the best of
the unpretending practitioners.
The laboratory scientists, taken as a group, have been
no less subject to the needs of the world of private profit.
The, universities turn out physicists and chemists who
work in the immediate and too often in the ultimate interest of acquisitive enterprisers. Like the graduates in
business administration, they have no more vision than
a mole, and grub in tunnels of the money-makers. Of
course, there are distinguished exceptions. But in the
main they are gleeful adjuncts of competitive design.
It does not matter, it would seem, whether the new
president of Johns Hopkins University is devoted to the
social studies, to engineering, the humanities, medicine or
the natural scences, so long as he recognizes that we
are emerging into a new world of cooperative adventure.
Learning and skill in all of these departments need to
be placed directly at the service of organized society,
and not to be first referred to the reluctance or interested
motive of private promotion. It is a question whether
an engineer, if he be one who has refused the leading
strings of acquisitive business, is not theoretically the
best fitted to mark the way for social development. His
passion is efficiency, and we must be rid of waste. While
equipped in theoretical analysis, the nature of his work
forces him to take practical account of many variables.
He must know how to be faithful to structural design,
and yet contrive to anchor his bridge on both sides of
the chasm.
The next president of Johns Hopkins University
should aim to conduct not only his own institution into
the nes/ day of production for use rather than profit,
but should be a candid counselor in persuading the country and, so far as his influence reaches, the world to this
course. The Johns Hopkins University now has an excellent opportunity to justify its position as a pioneer. This
University was the first to develop graduate studies in
America, but equally able recruits have been raised up
to join this march so that many now carry the same
standard. But the call is loud for a volunteer to step
out from the crowded ranks and lead in a new crusade.
The Johns Hopkins crest, by tradition and motto, will
we well chosen to flash back the sun which will shine on
this enterprise.

Valley Forge
A COMMENTARY
Baltimoreans are a queer people full of guile and
cunning. Never have I been able to determine their behavior in a given situation. They turn out in hordes
to see a play as inferior as "Ah, Wilderness" and arrive
at "Valley Forge" in a thin trickle.
This play—withal being damned by the D. A. R. (a
recommendation of which any playwright should be
justly proud) for indiscreet uncloaking of the real reasons the colonies made their war with England—is a
play of the people, by the people and for the AMERICAN people.
Philip Merivale is most inspiring as General Washington. His paramour—I should say, would-be paramour,
for let it be known that Washington remained true to
an unloved wife that whole long winter while the rest of
both British and American armies were to all appearances quite promiscuous—a compact little lady (offstage, Miss Gilmore) contrived to be the most completely superfluous person I have yet seen on any stage.
The rest of the cast is excellent.
"Valley Forge" will be good medicine for our economic colic, particularly for Maxwell Anderson's. Unfortunately, like the rest of the good medicine we get
nowadays, it is only a soothing syrup ranking somewhere in between Roosevelt's smile and the New Deal.
Anderson wrote a very timely play, ingredients: 10 per
cent bitters, 20 per cent sugar, 70 per cent alcohol. The
bitters consist of some ideas about why wars are made
which have been accepted by intelligent historians for a
number of decades; but this is a very two-faced sort of
play, for one comes out from under feeling very American and belligerent, ready to fight for any cause whatsoever, though it be even more misrepresented than the
Revolution was. After it has had its run and taken effect (it will be surely made into a movie), I shan't be
surprised to find Maxwell Anderson and the D. A. R.
living happily ever after.
The play was most melodramatic. I was profoundly
moved, and what frantic nose blowings and eye wipings
after each act just before the lights went on! A wellwrought play, but how connubial with the Vinson Bill
M. DARLING.
and high tariffs.

About 18 years ago Cliff Fischer,
Paris and New York agent and producer, had an argument with Lee
Shubert about the Montmarte cabaret, which was at that time situated
in the Winter Garden theater building. It was something to do with the
10% fee that Shubert took for rent.
Last week they spoke to each other for
the first time since then, and it is
rumored that they may be allied in
a new venture having something to
do with the French Casino, New
York.

Hal LeRoy, the dancer, who flung
many a feminine heart into the garbage can in "Harold Teen", is now
suing his father, George H. Schotte
for $65,000. It's all about an account
of Hal's earnings, which he turned
over to his sire to be redelivered
when the young hoofer attained the
age of twenty-one. It seems that the
old man drew it all out of a New
York bank, so the prodigal has
turned about and attached his
father's account in a Cincinnati bank.

Kenneth Rede, '22, acting supervisor of the Baltimore Relief Commission and an eminent authority on
literature, died November 21, at his
home in Guilford.
He was former president of the
Edgar Allan Poe Society, an organization founded by Dr. John C. French,
the University Librarian. Recently,
Rede wrote book reviews for the
Evening Sun, and was in charge of
educational work at the Western
Electric Company.
Rede, who was a native of Georgia,
received his early education at the
preparatory department of Mt. Vernon College and later was an instructor there. He was graduated from
the Hopkins in 1922 with a B. S. degree.

At its final meeting before the
Christmas holidays, the Cotillion
Board completed plans for the next
weekly dance to be held on Saturday,
January 5, from 9 to 12. The "Townsmen", a prominent local orchestra,

announced that this orchestra has
been secured for the remainder of the
bi-weekly dances. The prices of these
affairs will be the same as heretofore.

Announcement has again been
made by Mr. Maxwell Sauerwein,
assistant treasurer, that students
are eligible to attend tonight's banquet at the Merchants Club in honor of Dr. Ray Vail Orman.
Mr. Sauerwein explained that
uncertainty existed in certain quarters as to whether students could
attend, since they had not received
personal invitations.
"Although undergraduates will
be subject to the uniform $2.50
fee, they need not pay it in cash
immediately," he said. "I am certain that satisfactory arrangements can be made regarding the
payments. Tickets may be secured
at my office in Remsen Hall today, or at the Merchants Club
Prior to the banquet."
Coaches, sports writers, and "just
plain friends" who hate to see Van
Orman go will gather in a final farewell to Dr. Ray Van Orman at a
testimonial banquet to be sponsored
in his honor by the University Varsity Club tonight in the club's headquarters at 206 E. Redwood St. Festivities will open at 7 o'clock.
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
the University, has sent word that
he will attend, provided that injuries
he incurred in an automobile accident a few weeks ago permit him to
do so.
Tody Riggs, St. John's grid mentor,
Is the only one of the coaches tendered
Invitations who will definitely attend. Dick Harlow, of Western Maryland, has a speaking engagement in
Pittsburgh tonight while Curley Byrd
University of Maryland official must
attend a meeting in Richmond of the
Executive Board of the Southern
Conference, of which he is a member.
Washington College entertains its
first court foe tonight and Tom Kibler will have to be on the bench with
'Shoremen.
Harlow wrote to Carl W. Schmidt,
President of the Varsity Club, saying,
"I accepted two invitations to speak
In Pittsburg over a month ago and
regret that I cannot be with you to
Pay Van a tribute so richly deserved."
8Yrd and Kibler also expressed regret at being unable to participate in
a tribute to Van Orman.

Poetess Guest Of
Tudor And Stuart
A tea in honor of Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, prominent BaltiInore poetess, will be given today by
the Tudor and Stuart Club at 4
o'clock, at their club rooms in Gil10 .n Hall.
For many years Miss
Reese, who holds a high reputation
for her many poetic and other literarY works, has been an honorary
inernber of the group. Members of
the club will meet the guest of honor,
after which tea. will be served.
Dr. Elmer E. Stoll, professor of
flglis at the University of Minnesota, will give the annual lecture of
the Tudor and Stuart Club, February
16 in Levering Hall. Although Professor Stoll's topic has not been selected as yet, plans have been made
to hold a smoker and banquet in his
honor on that date. The numerous
honorary
and active members of the
club will be invited to
attend.

A gym class exclusively for girl
students in the graduate school
and College for Teachers has been
formed under the direction of Dr.
Wilson Shaffer, head of the intramural athletic department, and
Reuben Baer. The group includes
about 20 girls, who meet every
Wednesday from 8 to 10 p. m. in
the gymnasium.
In order to instruct the class in
basketball, volley ball and other
sports, a P. A. L. instructor has
been secured by the intramural
department. Plans have been
formulated to begin other classes
of girl students after the Christmas holidays.

Local High Schools
Visited By Twelve
Hopkins Students
Classes In Various Subjects
Observed By Largest Practice Teaching Group Here
Senior and junior high school days
returned for 12 students, seven women and five men, the largest group
in recent years to be registered in the
course in teaching in the secondary
schools, as they began observation
work for 1934-1935.
The students, of whom all but one,
a graduate student, are seniors in the
College for Teachers and the College
of Arts and Sciences, attended, during the past two weeks, secondary
school classes in English, history, biology, French, mathematics, commercial geography, and general science
to observe the techniques of teaching
in these subjects. What was noted in
detail was recorded on special blanks
which were submitted within 24 hours
to Dr. E. Earle Franklin, associate in
education here.
Observed Today
An observation in English was held
this morning at Junior High School
No. 49. Yesterday, the practice teachers saw a class in history taught at
the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.
The group visited a mathematics and
French class Wednesday morning at
the new Patterson Park Junior High
School.
Baltimore City College, where a
class in general science was observed, was visited Monday. Other
observations were held at Western
High School, Junior High Schools No.
1 and 41.
List Students
Enrolled in the class, registration
for which is not possible until specified
courses in education have been successfully completed, are: Maurice Sater, graduate student; Bertha Rodgin,
Katheryne Chambers, Alice Eklof,
Dorothy Girdwood, Regina Grau,
Bishop and Hyman M. Levin, seniors
in the College for Teachers; Howard
Fox, B. J. Stinnett, and Arthur Gutman, seniors in the College of Arts
and Sciences.
Ten individual observations in the
subject chosen for teaching, which
are to follow the current ten-group
observations, are to be followed by
a two-week period of practice teaching in the selected subject and in the
same class in which the individual
observations were made.

The Johns Hopkins University has been selected
by the Association of College Editors as one of the
150 American colleges and universities in which The
Literary Digest—A. C. E. Peace Poll will be conducted.
These questions will be asked on the poll ballots,
which are to be distributed in your postoffice boxes
during the week of January 7:
1. Do you believe that the United States can
stay out of another great war?
(a) If the borders of the United States were
invaded, would you bear arms in defense of
your country?
(b) Would you bear arms for the United States
in the invasion of the borders of another
country?
2. Do you believe that a national policy of AN
AMERICAN NAVY AND AIR FORCE
SECOND TO NONE will insure us against
the possibilities of another great war?
3. Do you favor government control of armament and munition industries?
4. Do you approve of the conscription of capital
in time of war, just as has been our historic
procedure in drafting man-power in time of
war?
5. Do you think that, in the pursuit of the stabilization of Peace, it would be a wise policy
for the United States to enter the League of
Nations?
Think over these questions during Christmas vacation. They require serious and lengthy consideration.—STANLEY E. BLUMBERG.

A Figure And His Figure
THE NUMBER "14" seems to have hovered over the
football career of Ray Van Orman with all the persistence of the proverbial income tax. He tutored droves
of Blue Jay gridders to relative pigskin glory for 14
years; undoubtedly the culmination of his uniquely successful coaching efforts was relized in the 14-13 triumph
over Maryland in 1927; first announcement of his intended resignation appeared in the local press on Wednesday, November 14; and tonight, exactly one month
later, he is to be tendered a farewell banquet in tribute
to his character and his achievements.
Possibly there's nothing much that can be added to
the laudations which are due to be heaped this evenrng
on Van's already laurel-bedecked head. But for fear lest
the student viewpoint may not be sufficiently emphasized by the speakers, we are taking the liberty to steal
a march on the toastmaster and exclaim with raised
glass:
Here's to you, Van, in appreciation of your contribution to Hopkins life. You taught us the chant of the
underdog—a grim chant, a solemn chant, but above all
a defiant and a triumphant chant. You didn't know what
overwhelming odds were, and you infused this selfsame
spirit in your men. For this we are deeply grateful;
without it we would be infinitely the poorer.
We hope you'll return to our midst often—say the
14th of every month; better, every 14th day. Until we
meet again, good-bye and good luck!

Culture—Physical
THAT THE athletic department has ushered in a gym
class expressly designed for the College for Teachers
girls probably will cause no end of eyebrow-lifting
among many of our masculine brethren, but it doesn't
surprise us in the least. It seems quite in harmony with
the trend which these young ladies have established
this year; namely, a typical Horatio Alger attitude of
refusing to sink in the academic swim.
Far more important than this rather trivial observation, however, is the commentary to which this project
perhaps unconsciously gives rise. It concerns itself with
the pampered, indolent manner of living which the modern miss has allowed herself to assume, with the inevitable result that she has lost to a great degree that
combination of endurance and hardiness which so
stamped her female progenitors. True, she participates
in many forms of athletics which were totally unknown
or prohibited to her ancestors, but in spite of these patent advantages she seems incapable of growing out of
the "hothouse aura" which, at least in the eyes of this
observer, seems constantly to cloak her. As the prospective occupant of a covered wagon, she would be a
total loss!
Understand that we are reciting from the diary of
the comparatively well-to-do damsel, the type that does

not immediately of its own volition or of necessity seek
employment in the downtown din and thereby lose practically all opportunity of perfecting itself physically,
but which on the contrary spends those nasty but usually necessary pre-marriage years as suits its particular
fancy. We contend that life has become far too easy for
these girls and that they for their part have made no
wholehearted attempts to resist the modern current of
abundant leisure which attend their every move. Even
in these days of depression the maintenance of their
unquestionable comforts and questionable pulchritude
appears to be the particular target of their parents'
forced financial stinting.
So it's with a mixed feeling of relief and elation that
we observe the formation of this feminine gym class. It
reminds us of that current song hit, "Love in Bloomers."

Dr. Mitchell Goes On Record
Following is an excerpt from "Johns Hopkins'
President," an article written by Dr. Broadus Mitchell and published in the Evening Sun, Tuesday, December 11. It offers a new interpretation of the modern purposes and values of a university, and as
such is worthy of reprint and reflection.
Our educational system, in both its public and private agencies, and from bottom to top, has too mucllent itself to the habit now outmoded. It has permittee
itself to be dedicated, by and large, to the preservation
of the established economic order. In the universities
this has been true not only in the departments of the
social studies, but in the more exact sciences as well. Le'
us say that investigators and teachers swore to lollow
truth wherever it led, still the light that guided them wal
apt to be furnished by the prevailing social system. Thir
is not to assess guilt, but simply to state a condition
Economists, sociologists and students of government haw
been preoccupied with description, often slavish and un
imaginative, of what is rather than with intelligent at
tempts at forecast. Where called upon for advice, they
have too often been willing to assume the role of mere
strategists for private enterprise. Presumably acquainted
with theory, they have in the event turned out to be
prime opportunists, hardly rising superior to the best of
the unpretending practitioners.
The laboratory scientists, taken as a group, have been
no less subject to the needs of the world of private profit.
The, universities turn out physicists and chemists who
work in the immediate and too often in the ultimate interest of acquisitive enterprisers. Like the graduates in
business administration, they have no more vision than
a mole, and grub in tunnels of the money-makers. Of
course, there are distinguished exceptions. But in the
main they are gleeful adjuncts of competitive design.
It does not matter, it would seem, whether the new
president of Johns Hopkins University is devoted to the
social studies, to engineering, the humanities, medicine or
the natural scences, so long as he recognizes that we
are emerging into a new world of cooperative adventure.
Learning and skill in all of these departments need to
be placed directly at the service of organized society,
and not to be first referred to the reluctance or interested
motive of private promotion. It is a question whether
an engineer, if he be one who has refused the leading
strings of acquisitive business, is not theoretically the
best fitted to mark the way for social development. His
passion is efficiency, and we must be rid of waste. While
equipped in theoretical analysis, the nature of his work
forces him to take practical account of many variables.
He must know how to be faithful to structural design,
and yet contrive to anchor his bridge on both sides of
the chasm.
The next president of Johns Hopkins University
should aim to conduct not only his own institution into
the nes/ day of production for use rather than profit,
but should be a candid counselor in persuading the country and, so far as his influence reaches, the world to this
course. The Johns Hopkins University now has an excellent opportunity to justify its position as a pioneer. This
University was the first to develop graduate studies in
America, but equally able recruits have been raised up
to join this march so that many now carry the same
standard. But the call is loud for a volunteer to step
out from the crowded ranks and lead in a new crusade.
The Johns Hopkins crest, by tradition and motto, will
we well chosen to flash back the sun which will shine on
this enterprise.

Valley Forge
A COMMENTARY
Baltimoreans are a queer people full of guile and
cunning. Never have I been able to determine their behavior in a given situation. They turn out in hordes
to see a play as inferior as "Ah, Wilderness" and arrive
at "Valley Forge" in a thin trickle.
This play—withal being damned by the D. A. R. (a
recommendation of which any playwright should be
justly proud) for indiscreet uncloaking of the real reasons the colonies made their war with England—is a
play of the people, by the people and for the AMERICAN people.
Philip Merivale is most inspiring as General Washington. His paramour—I should say, would-be paramour,
for let it be known that Washington remained true to
an unloved wife that whole long winter while the rest of
both British and American armies were to all appearances quite promiscuous—a compact little lady (offstage, Miss Gilmore) contrived to be the most completely superfluous person I have yet seen on any stage.
The rest of the cast is excellent.
"Valley Forge" will be good medicine for our economic colic, particularly for Maxwell Anderson's. Unfortunately, like the rest of the good medicine we get
nowadays, it is only a soothing syrup ranking somewhere in between Roosevelt's smile and the New Deal.
Anderson wrote a very timely play, ingredients: 10 per
cent bitters, 20 per cent sugar, 70 per cent alcohol. The
bitters consist of some ideas about why wars are made
which have been accepted by intelligent historians for a
number of decades; but this is a very two-faced sort of
play, for one comes out from under feeling very American and belligerent, ready to fight for any cause whatsoever, though it be even more misrepresented than the
Revolution was. After it has had its run and taken effect (it will be surely made into a movie), I shan't be
surprised to find Maxwell Anderson and the D. A. R.
living happily ever after.
The play was most melodramatic. I was profoundly
moved, and what frantic nose blowings and eye wipings
after each act just before the lights went on! A wellwrought play, but how connubial with the Vinson Bill

Kenneth Rede, Literary Critic And
Authority, Dies At Guilford,
November 21

Colic
COIIE

I

Kenneth Rede, '22, acting supervisor of the Baltimore Relief Commission and an eminent authority on
literature, died November 21, at his
home in Guilford.
He was former president of the
Edgar Allan Poe Society, an organization founded by Dr. John C. French,
the University Librarian. Recently,
Rede wrote book reviews for the
Evening Sun, and was in charge of
educational work at the Western
Electric Company.
Rede, who was a native of Georgia,
received his early education at the
preparatory department of Mt. Vernon College and later was an instructor there. He was graduated from
the Hopkins in 1922 with a B. S. degree.

Cotillion Dances Will
Feature "Townsmen"
At its final meeting before the
Christmas holidays, the Cotillion
Board completed plans for the next
weekly dance to be held on Saturday,
January 5, from 9 to 12. The "Townsmen", a prominent local orchestra,
have been secured to play for this
dance in Levering Hall. It was also
announced that this orchestra has
been secured for the remainder of the
bi-weekly dances. The prices of these
affairs will be the same as heretofore.

N. S. L. To Hear Mitchell
A discussion of "Campus Radicals"
will be Dr. Broadus Mitchell's topic
today when he addresses the Johns
Hopkins Chapter of the National Students League at 1 p. m. in room B.
Levering Hall.
All interested in hearing Dr. Mitchell are invited to attend.
